Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I was finishing up a balayage on a first-time client when I noticed her frown in the mirror. She hesitated, then quietly said, “It’s a bit warmer than I expected.” My heart sank. As a hairdresser, I know how important it is to make clients feel heard and happy, especially new ones. I wanted to reassure her, talk through options, maybe even adjust the tone right away. Just then, my phone buzzed in my apron pocket. It was a call from a legislative aide—someone I’d been trying to reach for weeks about the bill I’m fighting for. The message was urgent: “I have ten minutes to talk now.” My mind raced. If I missed this window, it could set our campaign back. But if I stepped away, I’d leave my client feeling dismissed and dissatisfied. I could feel the pressure mounting from both sides, each demanding my full attention, and I stood there, scissors in hand, torn between two worlds that suddenly felt impossible to balance.
